questions.text: A 6-year-old boy came to the emergency with knee pain and swelling for 3-4 months. On further clinical examination, his gums have a bluish-purple hue with areas of hemorrhages. An X-ray of the patient’s knee is given below. What would be the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Scurvy The clinical presentation and radiograph are consistent with Scurvy leads to the widening of the zone of provisional calcification which is demonstrated on the radiograph as a dense band ( White line of Frankel) at the growing metaphysis. Scurvy is a disease resulting from a deficiency of vitamin C (ascorbic acid), which is required for the synthesis of collagen in humans. This leads to decreased chondroitin sulfate synthesis which causes defective collagen growth and repair in the metaphyseal region of the long bone. This defect in type I collagen synthesis primarily affects osteoblastic function.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option:A. No classical radiographic features of rickets are seen, White line of Frankel on the radiograph suggestive of scurvy Option:B. No features of osteomalacia seen, White line of Frankel on radiograph suggestive of scurvy Option:D. No radiological features of fluorosis , White line of Frankel on radiograph suggestive of scurvy

questions.text: A 4-year-old thin male child presents to the OPD with a limp due to pain in the limbs. The mother states that there have been recurrent incidents of bleeding from the gums. On examination, hard painful swellings were felt on the chest. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Scurvy The key points in favor of diagnosis are: Painful limp Recurrent bleeding gums Swellings on the chest

Highyeild:

Scurvy : Pathogenesis : Vitamin C Deficiency --> Improper collagen maturation --> Defective collagen So, the osteoid is weakened. Mineralisation is Normal Collagen is also present in the blood vessels, so the blood vessels rupture and bleed easily Clinical Features: Pain in limbs ( Subperiosteal bleeding ) Bleeding Gums Scorbutic Rosary: Swellings present over the Costochondral junction Pain & Tenderness: Present

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. : Rickets presents with bowing of legs and does not present with above-mentioned features. Features of Rickets: Softening of the skull ( Craniotabes ) Frontal Bossing Rachitic Rosary Pigeon Chest / Pectus Carinatum ( Prominent Sternum ) Option: C. Osteopetrosis does not present with the above features. Features of Osteopetrosis: Pathological Fracture Anaemia, Leukopenia, Thrombocytopenia Hepatosplenomegaly Cranial Nerve Compression Option: D. Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis presents with a painful limp but it presents at an older age ( At puberty ) and the patient is obese with various endocrine disorders.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is presented to the OPD. The mother complains that the child’s joints can be moved in over the limit extent which is not seen in other children. Along with that, she feels that her child has bluish eyes. There is a recent history of fracture of the right leg. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis in this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Osteogenesis Imperfecta The points in the favor of Diagnosis are as follows: Hypermobile Joints ( Hyperlaxity ) Bluish eyes Age 3 years

Highyeild:

Osteogenesis Imperfecta : Type 1 Collagen Defect Skeletal dysplasia Clinical Features : Increased tendency of fractures ( MC in Lower limbs ) Hypermobility and Hyperlaxity Blue sclera Auditory defect ( SNHL ) [ Nerve compression due to soft skull ]

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Rickets does not manifest with above-mentioned Features of Rickets: Soft skull ( Craniotabes ) Frontal bossing Delayed closure of Fontanelle Costochondral Prominences: Blunt and Nontender( Known as Rachitic Rosary ) Prominent Sternum ( Pectus Carinatum / Pigeon chest ) Sulcus under the ribs where the diaphragm inserts ( Harrison Sulcus ) Option: C. Scurvy does not manifest with above-mentioned Features of Scurvy: Pain in limbs ( Subperiosteal bleeding ) leads to Pseudoparalysis Bleeding Gums Scorbutic Rosary Swellings present over the Costochondral junction Pain & Tenderness : Present Option: D. Phenylketonuria does not manifest with above-mentioned Features of Phenylketonuria: Blue Eyes Blond hair and fair skin Mousy / Musty body odor Mental Retardation

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents to the Orthopaedic OPD with a Left ulnar fracture. On examination, it was noted that the right leg of the child was malaligned. On asking about the history of the child, the parent stated that this was the third time the child has got his limb fractured in the period of one year. The range of movements at the joints of the child was more than the normal limit. Which of the following is the best operative treatment in this case scenario?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sofield Osteotomy The clinical features are suggestive of osteogenesis imperfecta. Sofield Osteotomy/Sekh kebab Osteotomy is the surgery done in such cases.

Highyeild:

The features that point towards the diagnosis of Osteogenesis imperfecta are: Recurrent fractures Hypermobility of joint Precious fracture healed with malalignment Explanation: Disease Type of Osteotomy Gun shot Deformity Modified French Osteotomy Developmental Dysplasia of Hip Salter Pemberton Osteotomy Hallux Valgus Chevron Keller Osteotomy Osteogenesis Imperfecta Soefield Osteotomy / Seekh Kebab Osteotomy

questions.text: During the Orthopedic rotation, the Professor presented with two similar-looking X-Rays. He asked his students to differentiate which X-ray shows Healing Rickets and which one shows Scurvy as both the X-Rays present with the development of a white line at the metaphysis. Which finding will help you to differentiate the X-Ray of Scurvy from Healing Rickets?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Wimberger Sign Wimberger sign denotes sclerotic margins around the epiphysis seen in the X-Ray of Scurvy. It can be used to differentiate scurvy from Healing rickets.

Highyeild:

Vitamin C is necessary for hydroxylation of lysine and proline to hydroxylysine and hydroxyproline, two aminoacids crucial for proper cross linking of triple helix of collagen. So deficiency causes failure of collagen synthesis or primitive collagen formation, throughout the body, including in blood vessels, predisposing to haemorrhage. It is also involved in neurotransmitter metabolism (conversion of dopamine to norepinephrine and tryptophan to serotonin), cholesterol metabolism (conversion of cholesterol to steroid hormones and bile acids), and the biosynthesis of carnitine. Vitamin C functions to maintain the iron and copper atoms, cofactors of the metalloenzymes, in a reduced (active) state. Vitamin C is an important antioxidant (electron donor) in the aqueous milieu of the body. Vitamin C enhances nonheme iron absorption, the transfer of iron from transferrin to ferritin, and the formation of tetrahydrofolic acid and thus can affect the cellular and immunologic functions of the hematopoietic system. PATHOLOGY In scurvy, there is defective formation of connective tissues and collagen in skin, cartilage, dentine, bone, and blood vessels, leading to their fragility. In the long bones, osteoid is not deposited by osteoblasts, cortex is thin, and the trabeculae become brittle and fracture easily. Clinical Features It develops after 6-12 months of dietary deprivation. For this reason it is not seen in neonates. The early manifestations are irritability, loss of appetite, low-grade fever, musculoskeletal pain, and tenderness in the legs, restlessness and even failure to thrive. These signs and symptoms are followed by leg swelling-most marked at the knees and the ankles-and pseudoparalysis. The infant might lie with the hips and knees semiflexed and the feet rotated outward. Subperiosteal hemorrhages in the lower limb bones sometimes acutely increase the swelling and pain, and the condition might mimic acute osteomyelitis or arthritis. A "rosary" at the costochondral junctions and depression of the sternum are other typical features. Rachitic Rosary Scorbutic Rosary Round smooth non tender Sharp and tender Gum changes are seen in older children after teeth have erupted and are manifested as bluish purple, spongy swellings of the mucous membrane, especially over the upper incisors Anemia, a common finding in infants and young children with scurvy, is related to impaired iron absorption and coexistent hematopoietic nutrient deficiencies including iron, vitamin B12, and folate. Hemorrhagic of scurvy include petechiae, purpura, and ecchymoses at pressure points; epistaxis; gum bleeding; and the characteristic perifollicular hemorrhages Other manifestations are poor wound and fracture healing, hyperkeratosis of hair follicles, arthralgia, and muscle.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A.Lateral metaphyseal spur at ends of metaphysis is produced by outward projection of the zone of provisional calcification. (Pelican spur Sign) Option: C. Scurvy line or scorbutic zone is a radiolucent transverse band adjacent to the dense provisional zone. Option: D. White line of Frankel’s line (zone of provisional calcification increases in width & opacity). This is seen due to the failure of absorption of calcified matrix

questions.text: The disease that results in deficient hydroxylation of the pro-alpha chains of collagen is known as ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Scurvy Scurvy occurs due to deficient hydroxylation of the pro-alpha chains of collagen.

Highyeild:

Scurvy Vit C is necessary for the hydroxylation of lysine and proline to hydroxylysine and hydroxyproline, two amino acids crucial for proper cross-linking of the triple helix of collagen. So deficiency causes failure of collagen synthesis or primitive collagen formation, throughout the body, including in blood vessels, predisposing to hemorrhage. Dysfunctional osteoblast (flat resembling fibroblast) causes failure of osteoid formation resulting in generalized osteoporosis Chondroblast & mineralization is unaffected causing the persistence of calcified cartilage approaching metaphysis seen radiologically as an opaque white line at the junction of physis and metaphysis (Frankel’s line) Osteoclasts are normal causing thin and fragile trabeculae and cortices of bone. Dentine formation in teeth is abnormal. Clinical Feature It develops after 6 — 12 months of dietary deprivation . For this reason, it is not seen in neonates. Earliest features are restlessness, fretfulness, irritability, loss of appetite, and failure to thrive Gums may be spongy and bleed. Subperiosteal hemorrhage is a distinct sign occurring most commonly in the distal femur & tibia and proximal humerus, causing excruciating, pain near the large joints. The child lies still to minimize pain or minimally move the affected limb (Pseudoparalysis) Hemorrhage in soft tissue, joint, kidney, gut, and petechiae may be seen Anemia & impaired wound healing is seen. Beading of ribs at the costochondral junction is seen ( Scorbutic Rosary ) Systemic reaction (fever) is absent initially.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Rickets is caused by a defect in the mineralization of the osteoid matrix caused by inadequate calcium and phosphate Option: C. Ehler Danlos is a congenital connective tissue disorder caused by a mutation in collagen-forming genes Option: D. Marfan syndrome is a congenital connective tissue disorder caused by a mutation of the fibrillin 1 gene

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy comes to you with his knee x-ray. You being the first-year ortho resident showed it to the consultant. As per the consultant, that knee x-ray has the white line of Frankel, Trummerfeld zone, Wimberger ring, Pelkin spur, "pencil-point" cortex. What is the diagnosis that comes to your mind first?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Scurvy These are the classical findings of patients with scurvy. X-Ray findings in scurvy:- The white line of Frankel:- widened zone of provisional calcification between epiphysis and metaphysis Trummerfeld zone:- transverse radiolucent band in the metaphysis adjacent to the Frankel line also known as the scurvy line Wimberger ring: - ring of increased density surrounding epiphysis Pelkin spur and fracture:- metaphyseal spurs and fractures thin cortices ("pencil-point" cortex) decreased trabeculae with ground-glass osteopenia subperiosteal elevation epiphyseal separation fractures and dislocations

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. It is defined as a deficiency of mineralization in children. Bone tissue throughout the skeleton is incompletely calcified and therefore softened. Rickets refers to a condition where it occurs before the closure of growth plates so that abnormalities of skeletal growth are superimposed. Option C. It is also a diaphyseal dysplasia characterized by failure of bone resorption due to functional deficiency of osteoclast. The bone contained an increased number of osteoclasts but these don’t resorb bone as evidenced by the absence of ruffled borders & clear zones a nd are unable to respond to PTH Option D. FLUOROSIS: Characteristic pathological feature is subperiosteal new bone accretion, and osteosclerosis (increased bone density).Most marked in vertebrae, ribs, pelvis, forearm, and leg bones, together with hyperostosis at the bony attachments of ligaments, tendons and fascia.

questions.text: All the following are radiological features of scurvy except which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Schmorl's node Radiological features of scurvy: Schmorl's node – the herniation of nucleus pulposus (NP) through the cartilaginous and bony end plate into the body of the adjacent vertebra.

Highyeild:

SCURVY Clinical features Bleeding gums Pseudoparalysis Scorbutic Rosary : Painful, sharp (ostochondral prominences. Anemia (impaired iron absorption) Poor wound healing Hyperkeratosis Arthralgia, Muscle Weakness X-ray satures: Osteopenia: Ground glass appearance Pencil tip cortex Wimburger sign White line of Frankel due to failure of - resorption of calcified matrix. Pelican Spur (Projection in metaphysis) Treatment: Vit. C supplement.

Pelken spur - The lateral part of the rarefaction appears as a triangular defect Option: C. Weinberger’s line - The epiphysis is surrounded by a thin white line

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the OPD with a fracture of the shaft of the femur. The mother is worried about severe deformities in all bones of the child. Also, there is a history of fracture thrice prior to this fracture with no significant history of trauma. Which of the following is wrong in regard to this disease of children?

options.label: A
options.text: There can be the presence of blue sclera

options.label: C
options.text: Multiple fractures can occur at regular intervals

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Delayed fracture healing In osteogenesis imperfecta delayed fracture healing is not seen Osteogenesis Imperfecta is a connective tissue disorder Occurs due to mutations of COL1A1 and COL1A2 genes which causes defective synthesis of Type 1 collagen production Defective production leads to the incompetent bone, vulnerable to fracture, secondary deformity, and joint laxity. Abnormality of non-skeletal collagen produces alterations in the sclera (blue sclera), dentinogenesis imperfecta, and deafness

Highyeild:

Osteogenesis Imperfecta Skeletal dysplasia (Hypoplasia) Characterised by genetic defect in Type 1 Collagen. Quantitative Qualitative AD/AR inheritance Clinical features: ↑ tendency for #s, Rate of # healing - Normal Lower limp # more common (Femur >) Growth arrest may be associated due to repeated #. Hyperlaxity of ligaments with Hypermobility of joints. Associated problems: Malunion/deformity OTTO Pelvis Dislocations of patella, radial head (although rare) When the disease is severe, skull is soft and membranous. Death is due to intracranial hemorrhage or Respiratory insufficiency. Ocular involvement: Blue Sclera Saturn's Ring or Arcus Juvenalis. Retinal detachment Hyperopia Auditory involvement: Seen in 40-50% cases (compression of nerve due to soft skull bones) Investigations: S. Ca and S. ph→ Normal Alk. This child suffers from osteogenesis imperfecta, in this disease there is an abnormality of non-skeletal collagen-producing alterations in the sclera (blue sclera) , dentinogenesis imperfecta, and deafness Option: B. This child suffers from osteogenesis imperfecta, Osteogenesis Imperfecta is a connective tissue disorder. Either there is a reduction in type I collagen or is replaced with poorly functioning mutant collagen. Option: C. questions.text: A 14-year-old girl child falls from a standing height and sustains the injury shown in the x-ray below. In addition to operative fixation of her fracture, she is scheduled to receive cyclical intravenous pamidronate administration as a treatment after the fracture is healed. options.label: C
options.text: No change in future fracture incidence

questions.correct_answer: D. An increase in bone density
questions.explanation:
Solution:

An increase in bone density In osteogenesis imperfecta there is improved bone density. It is a genetic disorder of connective tissue determined by quantitative and/or qualitative defects in type I collagen formation, one of the major components of fibrillar connective tissue in skin, ligaments, bones, sclera, and teeth. Either there is the reduction in type I collagen or is replaced with poorly functioning mutant collagen.
